column2:
Statement of Consent:
By clicking “I Agree” you indicate that you are at least 18 years of age; you have read this consent form or have had it read to you; your questions have been answered to your satisfaction and you voluntarily agree to participate in this research study. You may print a copy of this signed consent form.

 

I confirm that I am over 18 years of age, residing or working in the United States, and consent to participate in this study. I understand that my participation is voluntary and I may withdraw without penalty at any time. I also understand that I may optionally provide contact information at the end of this survey to be contacted for a follow up interview. 
If you agree to participate, please click “I Agree” below.
Note: Your responses will not be recorded until you hit "Submit" on the final page of the survey. If you do not feel like answering any questions or would like to stop part way through the survey, please be sure to click to the end of the survey and hit "Submit" to have your responses recorded (even if partial). Thank you!

column38: NOT ALL TRAILS ARE CREATED EQUAL! column38:
Biking/snowmobiling - should be restricted to trails with durable surfaces (including tough grassy surfaces)or purpose designated areas where impact on the environment and others is minimal.  Where they will not create ruts/swampy areas impacting the use of the trail by other parties.
ATV/off-road motorcycles/motorized vehicles - use should be highly restricted to durable surfaces or areas specifically designed/designated/managed for off-road activities and where environmental impact (rutting/swampy puddles/adverse impacts to terrain/flora/fauna) can be managed. Also where speeds are less of an issue than when using trails with hikers, walkers, runners, skiers, etc.
Not against these activities, just they are not always truly compatible with some other types of activities due to environmental impact, speeds, size of equipment.

column37: Practicing leave no trace principles and recognizing that's not just about your garbage, but also about conserving the trail beds and plant life by walking *through the center of the trail,* even if it's mud season, so you don't widen the trail! Hiked the Interloken Trail (FLT branch trail, 11.2 mi) on the Fourth, and the trail was so wide in many parts because of other hikers trying to go around the mud and water. It erodes plant life on the sides and probably does other negative things I don't know about.
column38: I've noticed that many people on trails, even avid hikers, feel the need to *touch* wildlife, whether it's bugs...or cows...on my day hike of the Interloken Trail this past weekend, I went through several pastures, and one was on a road that crossed the trail, so there were some people there, not hikers from the way they were dressed, and they had to reach out and try to touch the cows that had gathered next to the trail. People should not touch animals they encounter on trails. Let them be and let them do their thing. We are guests in their house. Look with your eyes. Take a picture.

column37: The most important is to be conscientious of other users, both those currently around you and future users. All trails should prioritize human contact (walking/running) and then non-motorized, human propelled, mechanized use. The simplest forms of use allow the greatest amount of access and therefore should be prioritized.
column38:
I am anti- horse-back riding because of the waste left on trails and destruction due to large animals. The horses also tend to be skiddish around other user groups in a way that is unpredictable and causes conflict.
I am anti- motorized travel unless there is a specific disability by the user that requires a motor. Motorized trail users create conflict because of their high rate of speed, unwanted noise, and pollution. E-bikes are part of the issue but I recognize that they create more potential trail users that otherwise may be put off by cycling.

column37: Nature viewing where feasible should be encouraged to engage trail users with their surroundings and promote a stronger sense of stewardship.
column38: On multi-use trails, motorized vehicles or fast moving bicyclists should be restricted and/or limited through increased trail rules or etiquette signage. Loud noises can disrupt a trail experience that may be intended to reduce stress or connect with ones environment, as well as being dangerous due to speeds and weight if it were to collide with a pedestrian. Fast cyclists that may be more suited to a roadway can also make other trail users feel unsafe or unwelcome if they do not utilize proper trail etiquette when passing, etc. Any activity that makes another trail user feel unsafe or unwelcome should be restricted in order to promote trails (specifically multiuse trails) as a place for all regardless of ability, background, or ethnicity.

column38: Some activities deserve dedicated spaces.  Mountain bike only, directional trails for example, allow mountain bikers to ride full-speed, safely.  Alternatively, people who want to walk their dogs shouldn't have to worry about a biker running into them at full speed.  But in some places, there may not be enough space for dedicated use trails, in which case equitable access to multi use trails is ideal.

column38: Trails need to be managed. Old ones need to be periodically re-evaluated for type of use or modifications needed to accommodate changing use preferences. New trails need to be designed around type of use, eg shared use versus single or restricted use. This should be guided by science, not by philosophical notions of what is appropriate on trails and what is not.

column55: There is an increased population stress on the "back country". On the one hand-I want people to have that experience, on the other-I have to say I'm a bit jaded with the amount of entitlement, lack of experience or common sense, ever increasing dependence on motorization, tools of distraction-such as phones and I-pods and GPS's, which all take away the awareness and reverence, curiosity, care and connection towards the fact that we are entering the space where the opportunity exists to be our more historically natural selves in the home we share with other creatures without "dominion." It is an experiential, educational apprenticeship that for many reasons is fading. Those of us who grew up with it-need to pass it on, and stand as a firm united front in protecting what is left of our public lands against development, motorization and multiple access to these mysterious and wild places. Helping one person at a time to understand and follow through with this is-I suppose-the "trail in".

column37: Equestrian use should be encouraged. Horseback riders maintain trails that others use, yet hikers and cyclists who are new to the forest are pushing riders out of the same trails they have maintained for decades and have even taken over areas marked for equine parking. Horseback riders tend to be avid conservationists and pick up after others’ trash. We also remove downed trees, keep trails passable, and try to be friendly and helpful to others, even the myriad of trail users who remain blissfully unaware of right of way, who bring dogs they cannot control, and even the ones who reach out and try to touch strange horses as they pass.

column38: Horses and hikers walk at similar speeds and are in the main, quiet contemplative folks.  Mountain bikes and E bikes are a thrill sport that disrupts with speed and danger to the other users.  We do share many trails with the bikers, but Wilderness trails should forever be maintained for non motorized use.  The need to get out of the high tech world and into nature as the Wilderness act envisioned is paramount to a good healthy experience.  I accept the dangers of Wilderness as part of the Wilderness experience.  I do not accept the need to be constantly on alert for a speeding bike coming around a narrow corner behind or in front of me.  Keep Wilderness as Wilderness.  An E bike is in fact a motorized machine in spite of many who might wish it were not counted as motorized.

column37:
Picking up litter should be encouraged on trails because it is a choking hazard for wildlife and pollutes the ecosystem.  Specifically picking up dog bags after using them to clean your dog is a real problem I see on the trail.  Maybe use of dog bags altogether should be discouraged since people are much less apt to carry out their dog bags than other trash.
Also dog walking should be encouraged on trails to give pets exercise and promote trails to people not necessarily interested in hiking.

column55: Environmental stewardship refers to responsible use and protection of the natural environment through conservation and sustainable practices.  Environmental stewardship is dealing with human's relationship to land and to the animals and plants which grow upon it.   It is the responsible use and protection of the natural environment through conservation and sustainable practices to enhance ecosystem resilience and human well-being!  A huge part is it means we protect and sustain our environment for future generations.

column37: Flagstaff, AZ is a municipal area and I think the trails should be maintained to handle people running, jogging and horse back riding. This mainly done by mitigating as much as naturally possible obstacles on the track way that cause fall injuries to ankles and knees. This higher level of maintenance needs more volunteers to build more water drainage structures because water erosion is what washes away loose material. I believe the web page has to be designed so that potential volunteers can contact a trail steward more directly.
column38: Motorized vehicles should be restricted. Trails maintained by manual labor and grubbing with hands are not designed to handle motorized vehicles. Dirt bike enthusiasts rear wheels tear into un-reinforced water bars and drainage humps and undo work. Some areas are in rocky areas where there is little soil, and that soil has been moved in from another source. Four wheel vehicles are too heavy for the trail and some people drive on the trail in order to try to turn it into a road. It destroys trail improvements and destroys undisturbed natural vegetation when the other wheel tract rolls over that parallel adjacent area of the trail. This stops when the trail becomes too rough for the vehicle to proceed further.

Most activities are get in/get out quickly, like a video game where the natural world becomes part of a gamified existence, especially for young people who have likely never experienced the world in any other way.
column38: Mission creep of any user group that involves mobility which includes bicycles, motorized transport of any kind, and equestrians. There is nothing principally wrong with any of the above, but how individuals and groups employ these mobility assists causes extreme trail conflicts and enmity between user groups. Typically, equestrians try to parcel off access to certain areas and mountain bikers will use speed and intimidation to discourage hiking and other trail activities. It also doesn’t help that in most cases mobility assist user groups don’t have to pay any subsidy to maintain trails/forest ecology despite doing more damage than people on foot and being able to afford tens of thousands in upfront costs for bikes/horses.

column44: I think it’s high time we start pushing people toward sustainable transport to reach these trails. What good is a zero emission bicycle if you shuttled it on a janky old Subaru 60 miles one way just to ride for an hour? We’re losing places to ride from fires because of climate related drought and increased heat. It sends the wrong message if we completely ignore the irony of how people who love the outdoors are emitting high levels of pollution for nonessential trips to the woods.
column55: Impact minimalism from door to destination. Got a friend with an electric car? Want to go to a trail event? Carpool. Want to reduce the human footprint on forest ecology? Reduce access. Want to reduce fire risk to remaining forests? Reduce access. Most people would consider themselves responsible individuals but it will take a group effort to undo the damage done by decades of wasteful neglect, self interested pursuits/pet projects, and corporate exploitation of wild spaces. Unfortunately this means less access/more responsible access over the coming decades or more fires, less habitat, and faster despeciation/deforestation. >97% of fires are human caused according to the Department of Forestry. The writing is on the wall. We have to become a three season outdoors community capable of self policing or things will get worse very quickly.

column124: The only side you should stand up for in turf wars between user groups is the side that can’t speak for itself. Forest ecology, rewinding habitats, and reducing impact are silent advocates that speak volumes above anything else.
column127: I’m not sure. Mountain bikers were stigmatized for a long time and have become sectarian as a result. A lot of negative energy creeps into sectarian user groups (not just mountain bikers) and about the only thing that makes sense after awhile is going back to how you got started enjoying the outdoors in the first place; solo. Even if it weren’t for discrimination from other user groups against mountain bikers and the sectarian tendencies there’s an industry problem where everyone from Redbull, to bike manufacturers, to Strava encourages a style of riding that is dangerous, noninclusive, and ultra competitive. I can’t begin to recall how many group rides I led where the tug of war between the Darwinists off the front and the recreating cyclists off the back kept us all split up and regrouping constantly. When you stop trying to lead and step outside that paradigm for awhile it becomes clear how there’s a toxicity that slowly creeps into you and other riders because of inside/outside forces trying to lead us all away from the simple pleasures of riding a bicycle. It sucks. I love the philosophy behind bike riding and wish all mountain bikers could have a come to Jesus moment on this. It would do everyone a lot of good.
